metadata.title: Functionalization of inorganic nanomaterials with pillar[n]arenes

sections.text:
This journal is©The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019 Chem. Commun., 2019, 55, 6817--6826 | 6817
Cite this:Chem. Commun., 2019, 55, 6817
Functionalization of inorganic nanomaterials with pillar[n]arenes
Jiao Chen, Yang Wang, Chenwei Wang, Renhua Long, Tingting Chen* and Yong Yao *
Pillar[n]arenes, which consist of hydroquinone units linked by –CH2– bridges at 2,5-positions, are a relatively new class of synthetic macrocycles since 2008. Their facile preparation and flexible modification properties
make them ideal stabilizers for inorganic nanomaterials. Furthermore, their symmetrical and columnar
architectures with very rigid and p-rich cavities endow them with rich host–guest properties. This Feature
Article provides an overview of the functionalization of inorganic nanomaterials with pillar[n]arenes and
their applications. These inorganic nanomaterials are classified into three major classes according to different
types of compositions: (1) novel metal nanomaterials; (2) hybrid metal nanomaterials; and (3) porous
materials. The applications of these nanomaterials such as catalysis, drug delivery, cancer therapy, and
sensing have been comprehensively discussed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In the past century, nanomaterials have become the research hot-spot due to their advanced properties originating from their nano sizes and superior applications in various areas such as catalysis, drug delivery, cancer therapy, sensing, and energy storage.1 Among various nanomaterials, inorganic nanomaterials (such as gold nanoparticles, Fe3O4 nanoparticles, and mesoporous silica nanoparticles) possess several advantageous features including high rigidity, chemical inertness, uniformity, and unlimited possibilities of surface functionalization compared with organic nanomaterials (such as liposomes, micelles, and vesicles).2 For instance, gold nanoparticles possessing high chemical stability, facile synthesis procedures, surface functionalization, biocompatibility, and tunable optical and electronic properties have many promising applications in sensors, nanoelectronics, biomedicine, catalysis, and surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy.3 Mesoporous silica nanoparticles possessing tailorable pore sizes and large surface areas have been considered as outstanding candidates for the transportation and controlled release of cargo molecules.4
Furthermore, as the newest class of macrocyclic hosts, pillar[n]arenes made up of substituted hydroquinone units linked by –CH2– bridges at the 2,5 positions present a hydrophobic core sandwiched between two functionalizable rims.5 Since pillar[n]arenes were prepared by Ogoshi in 2008,5a they have received tremendous interests by both chemistry and material scientists due to their interesting host–guest properties and potential applications in various areas. Compared with other macrocyclic hosts, pillar[n]arenes possess four typical characteristics: (1) easy synthesis and flexible functionalization. Alkylated pillar[5]arenes can be prepared in one step with a high yield by the condensation of 1,4-dialkyl-benzene. Furthermore, pillararene derivatives can be obtained using strategies including direct cyclization, cooligomerization and derivation of pillararene skeletons. (2) Pillar-like structures. Pillar[n]arenes have two identical cavity portals and possess symmetrical structures; thus, they are ideal host molecules for coordination with various guests. (3) More rigid and p-rich cavities. Combining the rich host–guest interactions of the pillar[n]arenes and the superior optical, electrical and magnetic properties of inorganic nanomaterials, in the past ten years, inorganic nanomaterials functionalized with pillar[n]arenes have been extensively investigated. Thus, this Feature Article provides an overview of pillar[n]arene-modified inorganic nanomaterials and their applications in various areas, such as catalysis, drug delivery, cancer therapy, and sensing.
2. Functionalization of novel metal nanomaterials with pillar[n]arenes
Novel metal nanoparticles have many advantages such as high chemical stability, easy synthesis, biocompatibility, and tunable optical, electrical and magnetic properties. Huang, Yang, Chen and my group have demonstrated several types of novel metal nanoparticles modified with pillar[n]arenes including gold nanoparticles,7 gold nanorods8 and silver nanoparticles.9

sections.heading: 2.1 Gold nanoparticles
sections.text:
In 2012, Prof. Huang and co-workers synthesized an imidazoliumfunctionalized water-soluble pillar[5]arene 2a and used it to prepare gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) in water.7a They found that the average size of AuNPs decreased with the increase in the molar ratio of [2a]/[Au3+]. Then, they used 2a–AuNPs as catalysts for the borohydride reduction of 4-nitroaniline in water, and the result showed greater sensitivity than that of AuNPs stabilized by the commonly employed capping or protective ligands; thus, the obtained 2a–AuNP catalysts have superior activity (Fig. 1). This work is a milestone in the area of the functionalization of inorganic nanomaterials with pillar[n]arenes.
Subsequently, in 2013, their groups synthesized the first amphiphilic pillar[5]arene 2b and used it to prepare AuNPs. Interestingly, they found that 2b–AuNPs can self-assemble into composite microtubes (CMTs) in water without any external assistance.7b By using UV-vis spectroscopy, Fourier transform
infrared spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and thermogravimetric analysis, they confirmed the structures of the composite microtubes. The CMTs are stable at a high temperature, in the presence of a strong acid or a strong base, or under sonication (Fig. 2). Importantly, the CMTs can be used in green catalysis with a yield loss less than 3% for 20 cycles. They believed that this work provides a new method to create amphiphilic nanoparticles for the fabrication of novel functional materials and devices by self-assembly.
Then, in 2013, Prof. Yang and co-works used carboxylatopillar[5]arene 2c as a ligand for the in situ preparation of AuNPs (Fig. 3). Furthermore, the interactions and assembly between guest molecules and 2c–AuNPs were also investigated and demonstrated. They found that the guest viologen I could mediate the assembly of the structures of 2c–AuNPs by controlling the amount added and the incubation time. Furthermore, the guest viologen II (viologen I dimer) could induce 2c–AuNPs to assemble into 1D and 3D structures. Based on the effects of viologen I on 2c–AuNPs, a small amount of viologen I could cause 2c–AuNPs to aggregate in a short time; thus, 2c–AuNPs can be used as optical probes for pesticide detection.7c They also anticipated that surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy-based selective assays can be used to leverage the selective binding ability of 2c toward guest molecules for ultrasensitive molecular detection.
Besides using mono-molecular pillar[n]arene as AuNP stabilizers as discussed above, pillar[n]arene-containing polymers were also synthesized and utilized to prepare AuNPs.7d In 2015, Prof. Chen and co-workers synthesized a narrow-disperse thermoresponsive

sections.heading: 2.2 Silver nanoparticles
sections.text:
Silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) coated with pillar[n]arenes were also investigated due to their stability, uniformity, and biocompatibility. In 2014, Prof. Xue and co-workers reported the controllable self-assembly and disassembly of AgNPs with 2c anchored on their surfaces (Fig. 5). The formation of silver assemblies was driven by the host–guest interactions between 2c and the water-soluble guest 2e, which has two paraquat units that glue the individual particles together.8a This caused a significant shift in the absorption spectrum accompanied by visible color changes from bright-yellow to brown. Furthermore, they found that the formed assemblies can be disassembled through the introduction of excess competitive host water-soluble pillar[6]-arene 2f, which forms complexes with 2e more favorably than 2c does. In addition, the recovered discrete 2c–AgNPs could be separated from the solution by centrifugation and redispersed in water. Thus, this process of the assembly–disassembly of 2c–AgNPs can be performed repeatedly with concomitant color changes (bright-yellow–brown–bright-yellow).
Considering that spermine and its analogues widely exist in nature and have been widely used in industries, the detection of spermine and its analogues is important because of their toxicity and their usage as tumor biomarkers. In 2014, Prof. Xue and co-workers prepared 2c-stabilized AuNPs in water. They found that a small amount of spermine or its analogues can induce the aggregation of 2c–AgNPs immediately (Fig. 6). Furthermore, the color of the particles changed from light yellow to brown.8b They confirmed that surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS)-based selective assays can be used to leverage the selective binding ability of 2c towards guest molecules for ultra-sensitive detection. Then, in the same year, their group synthesized a new water-soluble pillar[6]arene containing 12 imidazolium groups and used it to prepare AgNPs. Interestingly, due to the different sizes of pillar[6]arene and pillar[5]arene, these pillar[6]arene–AgNPs could be applied for the selective detection of Glu in water from eight common amino acids, while pillar[5]arene–AgNPs could not be applied.8c

sections.heading: 2.3 Gold nanorods
sections.text:
We know that gold nanorods (AuNRs) can rapidly convert the light absorbed at their SPR wavelengths into thermal energy and release the heat to the surrounding medium.9a This property is very important in in vivo applications. In 2014, Prof. Huang and co-workers prepared water-soluble pillar[6]arene 2f-stabilized AuNRs via ligand exchange. Then, AuNR-based supramolecular hybrid vesicles with diameter of 500 nm were successfully obtained when they added another amphiphilic guest molecule G2 into the solution of 2f-AuNRs. The release of the drug molecules after 2 min of NIR irradiation confirmed that these AuNR-based hybrid vesicles can be applied in NIRtriggered drug delivery (Fig. 7).9b
Another interesting work about pillar[n]arene-based AuNRs was reported by our group in 2018.9c First, we prepared a monocarboxylate-functionalized pillar[5]arene 2h with excellent solubility in an organic solvent. 2h could be adsorbed onto the surface of AuNRs spontaneously. Then, hybrid supramolecular materials were constructed from 2h–AuNRs and a linear dinitrile guest 2i driven by host–guest interaction (Fig. 8). Interestingly, we found that the hybrid supramolecular materials show dynamic near-infrared (NIR) and redox dual-responsive reversible properties. We used 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), optical microscopy, and specific viscosity to characterize the obtained materials and the reversible behaviors under external stimuli. We suggest that this NIR and redox dual-responsiveness property would be useful in the preparation of other smart materials and can also have potential in vivo applications.
3. Functionalization of hybrid metal nanomaterials with pillar[n]arenes
In addition to the extensive investigation of the functionalization of novel metal nanomaterials with pillar[n]arenes, inorganic nanomaterials containing more than one element, such as metallic oxide nanoparticles,10 quantum dots,11 heteropolyacid aggregates,12 metallic sulfide nanoparticles,13 and upconversion nanoparticles14 have been investigated because they combine the properties of different elements and can be applied in biological sensing, immunoassays, biomacro-molecular fluorescence labeling and bioimaging.

sections.heading: 3.1 Fe3O4 nanoparticles
sections.text:
Magnetic nanomaterials not only have very special magnetic properties, but also possess many new optical, thermal, chemical and biological properties. They have important applications in the fields of disease diagnosis and treatment, information storage, catalysis and waste treatment. For these or other reasons, Prof. Yang and co-workers prepared first pillar[n]arene 3a-based Fe3O4 NPs in 2013. 3a–Fe3O4 NPs showed better adsorption ability and strong superparamagnetism (Fig. 9).10a Pillar[n]arene layers, due to the pillar-shape and rigid macrocyclic structures, provide high extraction efficiency of the adsorbent to pesticides. They characterized the obtained 3a–Fe3O4 NP adsorbents via SEM, TEM, TGA, XRD, FT-IR and VSM. They found that after the optimization of several factors affecting the MSPE procedure, 3a–Fe3O4 NPs exhibited high adsorption capacity for target pesticides. Combined with HPLC-UV, a rapid, convenient, and matrixindependent method for the determination of MET, DIM, PYR, FLU, CYP, KRE, and TRI in beverage samples was established successfully, paving a new way for the sensing and detection of herbicides in food safety control.
Then, in 2019, their group constructed a new smart multi-stimuliresponsive hormone delivery system to regulate the release of gibberellin acid (GA3) for plant growth based on pillar[n]arene– Fe3O4 NPs (Fig. 10).

3a-functionalized Fe3O4 nanoparticles (3a–Fe3O4) were installed as nanovalves via host–guest interactions (3a–Fe3O4–HMSNs). Bidirectional pH-responsive supramolecular nanovalves were constructed for the first time and under acidic or alkaline conditions, hormones could be released from GA3-loaded 3a–Fe3O4– HMSNs (3a–Fe3O4–HMSNs–GA3) to promote the growth of plants. Interestingly, 3a–Fe3O4–HMSNs–GA3 could also respond to other stimuli including 1,4-butanediamine (BDA) and ultrasound. This smart delivery system was successfully applied in plants such as Arabidopsis thaliana (A. thaliana) and cabbages, and the experimental results suggested that the 3a–Fe3O4–HMSNs–GA3 hybrid nanomaterials can obviously promote the growth of both plants. Therefore, they envisioned that this magnetic multi-stimuliresponsive system will hopefully play an important role in promoting agricultural industry development.
Unlike Prof. Yang and co-workers who used pillar[n]arene as the stabilizer for Fe3O4 NPs, Prof. Diao and co-workers constructed another type of pillar[n]arene-based Fe3O4 NP system. They synthesized a new amphiphilic pillar[5]arene 3b with five alkyl chains and five oligomeric glycol groups. 3b could self-assemble into reversible responsive supramolecular vesicles in water. They also found that the model molecule 3c could not self-assemble under the same condition, indicating that the framework of pillar[5]arene is very important for 3b to self-assemble in water. The supramolecular vesicles were confirmed to be a bilayer with a diameter of B100 nm by different characterizations such as DLS, TEM, and SEM. These vesicles were stable even after several weeks. Additionally, under external physical stimuli, these vesicles also showed reversible thermal and dynamic properties. More interestingly, Fe3O4 NPs could be incorporated into the bilayer of the 3b-vesicles to form hybrid magneticresponsive supramolecular vesicles, and these hybrid vesicles could be used in magnetic controlled release (Fig. 11).10c

sections.heading: 3.2 Quantum dots
sections.text:
Quantum dots (QDs), with unique photophysical properties and size-controlled fluorescence, have attracted significant interest
over the past few decades and have been widely used in optical sensors, optoelectronics and biological imaging. In 2013, Prof. Yang and co-workers modified 2c on the surfaces of CdTe QDs via the ligand-exchange method, paving a new way for the stabilization of nanocrystals with multi-carboxylated group-functionalized organic compounds (Fig. 12).11a The newly synthesized 2c–QDs were stable in aqueous media at room temperature and showed potential as a candidate for the detection of the herbicide paraquat based on their special photophysical properties. Meanwhile, 2c–QDs could form an aggregated supramolecular network upon the addition of bridged bis(MV) via supramolecular host–guest interactions. These 2c–QDs, combining the properties of QDs and pillar[n]arenes, are expected to serve as efficient chemical sensors or detectors for various analyses in the future.
Liquid quantum dots (QDs) have been used as fluorescent film sensors. Constructing a macroscopic, responsive, liquid QD system for lysine (Lys) is a challenging task. To achieve a selective macroscopic response towards Lys, in 2016, Prof. Li and co-workers presented a new strategy for integrating the host–guest chemistry into a liquid QD system (Fig. 13). Water-soluble pillar[5]arene 3d was designed and synthesized as a host. 3d was introduced onto the surface of PEG1810-modified QDs by host–guest interactions to obtain liquid 3d–1810-QDs. The interaction between 3d and Lys was stronger than that between 3d and PEG-1810, causing 3d to be released from the 1810-QD surface in the presence of Lys; this resulted in macroscopic fluorescence quenching.11b This smart material showed promise in amino acid sensing and separation.
Besides pillar[5]arene, QDs modified by pillar[6]arene were also investigated. In 2018, Prof. Yang and co-workers prepared water-soluble pillar[6]arene 2f-functionalized nitrogen-doped carbon quantum dots (2f–NCQDs) for the first time.11c They found that 2f–NCQDs showed excellent supramolecular recognition capability and a superior electrochemical sensing performance towards TNT (Fig. 14). sections.heading: 3.3 Heteropolyacid aggregates
sections.text: Polyoxometalates (POMs) are a class of early transition metal– oxygen anionic nanoclusters with unique chemical and physical properties. In 2018, Prof. Liu and co-workers successfully constructed hybrid 2D nanosheets containing a Keggin POM and water-soluble pillar[6]arene 3e by a simple ionic self-assembly method (Fig. 15). These hybrid 2D nanosheets can be used as efficient catalysts in dye degradation.12 The macrocyclic cavity of 3e plays a dominant role in building 2D structures and the enhancement in degradation efficiency. These findings may open a promising avenue to construct ionic-organic hybrid materials with a synergistic effect between POM and macrocyclic molecules to show more synergistic effects.

sections.heading: 3.4 CuS nanoparticles
sections.text:
Photothermal therapy (PTT) based on optical absorbing agents that can convert near-infrared (NIR) light energy into thermal energy for causing hyperthermia to kill cancer cells has attracted tremendous attention in recent years. The resulting smart 2c–CuS NPs exhibited excellent photo-thermal ablation capability to HepG2 cells upon irradiation with a laser at 808 nm. The chemotherapeutic drug doxorubicin hydrochloride (DOX) was further loaded onto 2c/G-CuS NPs via electrostatic interactions between positively charged DOX and negatively charged 2c to give 2c/G-CuS–DOX with a high drug-loading capacity up to 48.4%. The weakening of DOX–2c interactions in an acidic environment promoted pH-responsive drug release from 2c/G-CuS–DOX. Significantly, this multifunctional supramolecular nanosystem showed a remarkably enhanced therapeutic effect through the combination of targeted chemotherapy and photothermal therapy upon an in vitro cell study (Fig. 16). Moreover, a preliminary in vivo study demonstrated that 2c/G-CuS and 2c/G-CuS–DOX have good biocompatibility and excellent tumor inhibition effects upon near-infrared laser irradiation.

sections.heading: 3.5 Upconversion nanoparticles
sections.text:
Upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) are a class of hybrid nanoparticles that can convert near-infrared light to visible light via sequential electronic excitation. As we all know, nearinfrared light causes less damage to body tissues as compared with UV light, making UCNPs highly suitable for applications in in vivo imaging and photodynamic therapy. In 2018, Prof. Yang and co-workers established an efficient and feasible method for the preparation of water-dispersed UCNPs by the surface-ligand exchange of oleate with phosphoryl pillar[5]arenes. They further used these nanoparticles for the successful preparation of a pH-responsive drug delivery system via the host–guest interactions between pillar[5]arene and cargoes.14a In the same year, Prof. Sun and co-workers constructed a novel supramolecular upconversion nanosystem via host–guest interactions based on watersoluble pillar[5]arene 2c and 15-carboxy-N,N,N-trialkylpentadecan-1ammonium bromide (G3) to produce 2c–G3–UCNPs, which could be loaded with DOX for dual mode bioimaging-guided therapeutic applications.14b
4. Functionalization of inorganic porous nanomaterials with pillar[n]arenes
In the past decade, inorganic porous nanomaterials have been intensely investigated for the controlled release of small molecules due to their high rigidity, chemical inertness, uniformity, tailorable pore sizes, and large surface areas as well as the unlimited possibilities of surface functionalization.15 The functionalization of inorganic porous nanomaterials, such as mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs)16 and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs),17 with pillar[n]arenes on porous solid scaffolds has emerged as a powerful strategy to afford smart controlled release via rational stimulating operations, which comprise divergent external stimuli such as pH, temperature, redox, enzymatic activities, NIR, and competitive binding.

sections.heading: 4.1 Mesoporous silica nanoparticles
sections.text:
In 2013, Prof. Yang and co-workers constructed the first pillar[n]arene-modified mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs). In the present study, MSNs of diameter B140 nm were fabricated based on organic stalks containing pyridinium termini, which complexed with 2c rings under neutral and basic conditions; here, they could trap cargo molecules irrespective of their charge. The release of the cargo molecules (dyes or drugs) could be achieved by lowering the pH or adding a competitive binding agent for the 2c derivative; following the testing of its cytotoxicity by the MTT method with three different cell lines, it was shown to be biocompatible (Fig. 17).16a
Then, in 2016, their group fabricated a new drug delivery system based on mesoporous silica nanoparticles doped by carboxylatopillar[5]arene 2c-modified gold nanoparticles, which demonstrated good responses to competitive binding and temperature variation.16b This multifunctional nanosystem combined the excellent characteristics of two kinds of nanoparticles and utilized a supramolecular host–guest approach for on-demand cargo release. This 2c–AuNP-capped MSN-Q hybrid nanosystem

with excellent responsiveness to the competitive binding agent and temperature stimuli as well as the ability to load and transport cargo irrespective of the cargo molecular size is expected to be an ideal candidate for drug delivery (Fig. 18). Significantly, the AuNP-capped MSN-Q hybrid nanosystem, with tremendous latent capacity to achieve remote-controlled and ‘‘ladder’’ pulsatile release in response to a noninvasive operation, provides practical insights into the design of advanced nanocarriers towards synergistically increasing the drug delivery efficiency for chemotherapies in diseases.
In order to improve the effectiveness of cancer therapy and reduce the adverse effects of conventional chemotherapy, the development of less toxic, biocompatible, decomposable and pH-responsive nano-containers is of great importance. In 2016, Prof. Huang and co-workers designed and synthesized a novel decomposed nano-container by doping 2c onto hollow mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) via host–guest complexation.16c This nano-container decomposed into small water-soluble fragments to achieve highly efficient release of the loaded anticancer drug doxorubicin. Importantly, the complexation of 2c molecules with MSNs significantly improved the inhibition of tumor growth in vivo with minimal side effects, which can be attributed to the pH responsiveness of the host–guest interactions (Fig. 19). Under extracelluar conditions, the host–guest complexation between 2c and HMNPs enhanced the loading of doxorubicin molecules. However, this host–guest complexation was prohibited under low pH conditions in intracellular lysosomes, due to which doxorubicin was released readily from the vector. The present novel drug delivery system demonstrates the great potential of host–guest complexation for cancer therapy improvement.

sections.heading: 4.2 Metal–organic frameworks
sections.text:
In 2016, Prof. Yang and co-workers constructed monodisperse mechanized nanocarriers based on MOFs and pillarene-based supramolecular switches as gatekeepers for the first time by combining post-synthetic modification with stimuli-responsive host–guest chemistry. Negatively charged 4a macrocycles were introduced to encircle the Py stalks via host–guest complexation to form [2]pseudorotaxanes as the movable elements of the nanocarriers, thereby realizing drug encapsulation (Fig. 20).17a This unique MOF-based nanovalve system showed pH- and/or
competitive binding agent-triggered controlled cargo release with negligible premature release, large pore sizes for drug encapsulation, non-cytotoxicity, good biodegradability and biocompatibility, and potential application in cell imaging, which will open new avenues in targeted drug delivery and controlled release of therapeutic agents, especially in the treatment of cancer diseases. Their group also reported other contributions about the functionalization of MOFs with pillar[n]arenes: in 2015, they reported Zn2+-triggered drug release from biocompatible zirconium MOFs equipped with pillar[5]arene-based supramolecular gates;17b in 2018, they reported a proof-of-concept nanoplatform constructed from polypyrrole@UiO-66 nanohybrids and 2f-Nanovalves for effective chemophotothermal therapy via the integration of folic acid-based active targeting and supramolecular nano-valve-based passive targeting.17c

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this Feature Article, we discussed the formation and applications of various pillar[n]arene-modified inorganic nanomaterials such as novel metal nanoparticles, metallic oxide nanoparticles, metallic sulfide nanoparticles, quantum dots, heteropolyacid aggregates, MSNs, and MOFs. By combining the host–guest properties of pillar[n]arenes and the superior optical, electrical and magnetic properties of the inorganic nanomaterials in one system, these nanomaterials responding to a variety of internal and external stimuli, including pH, enzymes, redox reactions, competitive binding, light, and thermal stimulation, were widely applied in many areas. However, there are numerous challenges and opportunities in this emerging research field. First, most pillar[n]arenes modified on inorganic nanomaterials are pillar[5]arenes; there are very few studies about pillar[6]arenes and no reports about pillar[7–10]arenes. Therefore, the development of large-sized pillar[n]arene-modified inorganic nanomaterials is very important. Second, the major efforts in this area have been focused on the fabrication of pillar[n]arene-modified inorganic
nanomaterials, while relatively less attention has been paid to the applications of these materials. There is no doubt that the investigations of their potential applications in materials science, biology and environmental science should gain more attention in the future. Altogether, we believe that inorganic nanomaterials based on pillar[n]arenes will be quite promising in the near future, and numerous nanomaterials with novel structures and functionalities will be fabricated and applied in various areas.

metadata.abstractText: Pillar[n]arenes, which consist of hydroquinone units linked by –CH2– bridges at 2,5-positions, are a relatively new class of synthetic macrocycles since 2008. Their facile preparation and flexible modification properties make them ideal stabilizers for inorganic nanomaterials. Furthermore, their symmetrical and columnar architectures with very rigid and p-rich cavities endow them with rich host–guest properties. This Feature Article provides an overview of the functionalization of inorganic nanomaterials with pillar[n]arenes and their applications. These inorganic nanomaterials are classified into three major classes according to different types of compositions: (1) novel metal nanomaterials; (2) hybrid metal nanomaterials; and (3) porous materials. The applications of these nanomaterials such as catalysis, drug delivery, cancer therapy, and sensing have been comprehensively discussed.
